title: 108_s1967
content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. Section 19 of the Federal Reserve Act allows the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to determine exceptions. Amendments to Public Law 93-100 clarify that institutions prohibited by law cannot offer demand deposit accounts. Effective date for these amendments is specified. The amendments made by paragraph (1) regarding deposit accounts will take effect 2 years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of prohibition on payment of interest on demand deposits under various acts and joint rulemaking required within 2 years. Federal banking agencies will issue regulations allowing the payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. The regulations will define the scope of authorization, types of accounts included, and any limitations or restrictions. These regulations must be effective within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. Definitions for this subsection will also be provided. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect within 2 years of the enactment of the Act. Definitions for terms like "depository institution," "transaction account," and "Federal banking agency" are provided in this subsection. The repeal will become effective either 2 years after the Act's enactment or when final regulations under subsection (b) take effect. SEC. 4. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may issue regulations on the payment and distribution of these earnings to the institutions. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The distribution of earnings to depository institutions and their responsibilities, along with definitions, are outlined in the amendment. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank. Definitions and technical amendments are also included in the amendment. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at a Federal Reserve bank. Section 19 of the Act is amended to make technical and conforming changes, including the removal and redesignation of certain subparagraphs. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding certain activities from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The text chunk discusses expenses related to providing banking services for an escrow account, forbearance from charging fees, and benefits to the account holder.
